They came to a chasm where a fifty-foot section of catwalk had collapsed into the darkness below, a gap too wide to jump. Kaelen’s gaze immediately went to a massive, rust-pocked coolant pipe that spanned the gap ten feet above their heads, a brutish, high-risk solution. Before he could voice the plan, Elspeth laid a hand on his good arm, her touch surprisingly firm. She pointed not up, but to the side, at a narrow, crumbling concrete ledge, barely a hand’s-width, that followed the curve of a vast, silent storage tank. It was a path that required balance and nerve, not brute strength. For a moment, his analytical mind calculated the probabilities of a fall, the structural instability of the pre-Hegemony concrete. Her path was riskier, but faster. He gave a single, sharp nod of assent, a flicker of acknowledgement that her input was valid data. She went first, moving along the ledge with the confidence of a tightrope walker, her arms out for balance, a slim silhouette against the distant, fiery glow. Kaelen followed, his progress a clumsy, brutal counterpoint. He couldn’t trust his balance, so he used his prosthetic, punching the brass fingers into the crumbling concrete wall, creating his own handholds, his mechanical strength turning the impossible traverse into a matter of grim, agonizing work.

They continued their ascent, their silent, strange partnership solidifying with every obstacle overcome. The higher they climbed, the more the factory’s ancient, automated systems became apparent. They rounded a corner to find their path blocked by a flickering, shimmering curtain of red light, a laser grid designed for inventory control, still active after decades of disuse. It swept the corridor in a complex, three-part cycle. Elspeth instinctively recoiled, but Kaelen held his ground, his gaze fixed on the pattern. “Three-one-two cadence,” he stated, the words clipped, devoid of explanation. “It’s inefficient. There’s a half-second lag after the third sweep. Move on my mark.” He was no longer a wizard assessing a ward; he was an engineer identifying a design flaw. He watched the lasers cycle once, twice, his mind a perfect clock. “Now.” He moved, his lurching, heavy gait surprisingly fast, clearing the grid just as it began its next cycle. Elspeth followed a breath later, her own movements a blur of grace. She glanced back at him, her expression a mixture of awe and renewed suspicion. The monster knew the secret songs of machines.

Finally, a last, rust-eaten ladder led them through a hatch and out into the open air. The change was a physical shock. The oppressive, recycled heat of the factory was replaced by the biting cold of the Vesperian night, the air tasting of rain and ozone. The roar of the factory was a dull, distant rumble, replaced by the howl of the wind as it whipped around the forest of smokestacks and communication spires that dotted the vast, flat expanse of the roof. Below them, Vesperia was a breathtaking, horrifying tapestry of light and shadow, a sea of flickering arc-lamps and glowing windows stretching to the horizon, dominated by the colossal, spire-piercing silhouettes of the vampire demesnes, which loomed over the city like the tombs of sleeping gods. In the center of the rooftop was their goal: a series of circular, illuminated landing pads, on one of which sat a silent, waiting cargo drone.

It was not a thing of elegance. It was a brutal piece of Hegemony engineering, a flattened, insectoid chassis of dull grey metal with six powerful, multi-jointed legs that served as landing struts. A single, dull red optical sensor glowed on its front, and its flat upper surface was clearly designed to carry heavy, magnetized cargo containers. It was a workhorse, a flying flatbed truck, and it was currently dormant, its systems in a low-power standby mode as it awaited its next automated command. Kaelen limped toward it, his prosthetic arm hissing softly, his gaze sweeping the area. “This is it,” he said, his voice barely audible over the wind. “Its flight controller is fire-walled, but the manual maintenance port should allow a root-level command injection.” He looked at her, his eyes cold and intense. “I will need thirty seconds. Watch the hatch. Scream if anything comes through it.” It was a crude plan, but it was all they had. He was placing his life, and hers, on her ability to be a reliable sensor.

She nodded, her jaw tight, and took up a position near the rooftop hatch, her eyes fixed on the darkness below. She ripped a jagged piece of metal from a broken vent cover, its sharp edge a pathetic but deeply necessary weapon. Kaelen turned his attention to the drone. He located the maintenance port, a small, armored panel near the machine’s primary power conduit. He didn’t have the key. He didn’t need one. He slammed the heel of his prosthetic hand against the panel, the force of the pneumatic blow denting the metal and shattering the internal lock. He pried the ruined panel open, revealing a complex nest of fiber-optic cables and glowing crystal data-ports. This was the Wayfinder’s domain. His left hand, nimble and sure, plunged into the machine’s guts, while his prosthetic braced his body against the drone's chassis. He found the master data-port, a pulsating blue crystal. He didn’t have an interface cable. Instead, he pressed the fingertips of his left hand directly against the crystal, closed his eyes, and pushed his consciousness into the machine.

The drone’s internal systems were a frigid, orderly world of pure logic, a stark contrast to the chaotic energies of magic. Kaelen felt the machine’s immune system detect his presence, an unauthorized intrusion, and begin to erect firewalls of cold, sharp code. But he was faster. The Wayfinder’s mind, the engineer’s mind, moved with a speed and intuition that was breathtaking. He didn’t fight the firewalls; he found their backdoors, the diagnostic loopholes left by their lazy creators. He didn’t rewrite the flight plan; he erased it and wrote a single, new, overriding command: *Ascend. Maximum velocity. Vector 0-0-0. Maintain altitude until new command.* The strain was immense. A trickle of blood ran from his nose, hot against the cold skin of his lip. The drone’s single red eye flickered, then glowed with a sudden, intense green. The low hum of its standby mode escalated into the high-pitched, rising whine of turbines spinning to life.

“It’s coming!” Elspeth’s voice was a sharp cry of alarm. A beam of white light stabbed up from the hatch, followed by the clatter of armored boots on the ladder. Kaelen pulled his hand back from the console, his connection severed. “Get on!” he roared, stumbling back from the drone. They scrambled onto the flat cargo bed, the metal vibrating with a power that shook them to their bones. Kaelen looked back to see the top of a black-armored Inquisitor’s helmet appear in the hatchway. The drone’s engines screamed. Without the gentle, cushioned lift of a standard takeoff sequence, the machine leaped from the roof with a brutal, sickening lurch of pure vertical thrust. Kaelen and Elspeth were slammed against the deck, the g-force a crushing weight on their chests. The refinery, the Stygian Maw, the entire world of fire and despair they had just escaped, fell away below them at a terrifying speed, shrinking into a glowing, chaotic wound in the city’s dark flesh. They were airborne, a stolen piece of the Hegemony’s machinery, ascending into the bruised, rain-swept darkness of the Vesperian sky, exposed, hunted, and for the first time in a long time, horribly and terrifyingly free.
